[[File:William Kolodney 92nd St. Y.jpg|thumb|Dr. William Kolodney]] '''William Kolodney''' (1899 – January 18, 1976) was a Russian-born American cultural educator and program director for two major New York City institutions, the [[92nd Street Y]] and the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].
==Early life and education== Kolodney was born in [[Minsk]],<ref>[http://www.jta.org/1976/01/22/archive/william-kolodney-dead-at-76 "William Kolodney Dead at 76"], [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]], January 22, 1976, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> and his family moved to America when he was 4 years old. He attended [[New York University]] as an undergraduate and earned a master's degree and a Doctorate from [[Columbia University]].<ref name=NYTimesObit>[https://www.nytimes.com/1976/01/19/archives/dr-william-kolodney-dies-at-76-brought-arts-to-the-92d-st-y.html "Dr. William Kolodney Dies at 76; Brought Arts to the 92d St. 'Y'"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 19, 1976, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> His dissertation was based on his work at the [[92nd Street Y]], describing its transformation during his tenure into "a major arts institution".<ref name=Rothstein1992>Rothstein, Edward. [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/29/arts/classical-view-lessons-for-the-future-may-lurk-in-the-past.html "Classical View; Lessons for the Future May Lurk in the Past"], ''The New York Times'', November 29, 1992, accessed July 25, 2017</ref>
==92nd Street Y== Kolodney created the educational program for the [[Jewish Community Center|YMHA]] in Pittsburgh in 1926.<ref>[https://www.92y.org/uptown/school-of-the-arts/harkness-dance-center/about/celebrating-75-years-of-dance-at-92nd-street-y/our-history.aspx "Our History"], [[92nd Street Y]], accessed July 25, 2017</ref> In 1935, he joined the 92nd street Y in New York as Educational Director, instituting a wide-ranging educational program. He made the "Y" a center for chamber music, poetry readings, and dance performances.<ref name=Rothstein1992/> He was guided by idealistic principles. He decided "not to popularize or glamorize knowledge through publicity methods designed to attract large numbers." At the same time, he felt that fees for "Y" programs "should be small enough to enable the clerical or the salaried worker with a modest income to enroll in any activity which might meet his needs and interests."<ref name=Rothstein1992/>
Kolodney felt that music was a way to educate the emotions and that each person "responds differently to every sound, from the wind in the trees to a Shostakovich symphony."<ref name=Tolchin>Tolchin, Martin. [https://query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch/#/william+kolodney+martin+tolchin+1960+%22attuning+the+young+to+music%22/ "Attuning the Young to Music"], ''The New York Times'', June 26, 1960, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> He presented great musicians such as [[Rudolf Serkin]], [[Myra Hess]], [[Gregor Piatigorsky]], [[Erica Morini]], and [[Joseph Hoffman]] as well as the [[Budapest String Quartet]] in annual series. He established the Y School of Music under the direction of [[Abraham Wolf Binder]], who believed that it was more important to teach a child how to listen to music than to play an instrument.<ref name=Tolchin/>
In 1936 Kolodney invited [[Martha Graham]] to give a dance recital as part of the new Dance Center at the "Y". During the next ten years she performed there as a solo recitalist or with her group. Other dancers or faculty at the "Y" have included [[Doris Humphrey]], [[Charles Weidman]], [[Hanya Holm]], [[Anna Sokolow]], [[Agnes de Mille]], [[Paul Taylor (choreographer)|Paul Taylor]], [[Jose Limon]] and [[Alvin Ailey]] among others. When Ailey received New York's Handel Medallion, he said he could not have formed his company without the support of Kolodney.<ref>Rosenthal, John P. [https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/12/opinion/l-martha-graham-wrought-emotion-into-dance-her-role-at-the-y-420091.html "Martha Graham Wrought Emotion Into Dance; Her Role at the 'Y'"], Letters to the Editor, ''The New York Times'', April 12, 1991, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> In 1974, Agnes de Mille said "No other institution in the United States has done more for American dance. Without William Kolodney, there simply was no place to go. He gave us a stage and an intelligent audience. He taught us to hope."<ref>Kisselgoff, Anna. [https://www.nytimes.com/1974/04/23/archives/dance-tribute-to-the-y.html "Tribute to the 'Y'"], ''The New York Times'', April 23, 1974, accessed July 25, 2017</ref>
Kolodney created The Poetry Center at the "Y" in 1939 "to meet the needs of the very few persons in New York to whom poetry offers the theological, ethical and esthetic equivalents of traditional religion".<ref>Farrell, William E. [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1980/12/20/111325182.html?pageNumber=30 "About New York: Echoes From a Venerable but Lively Auditorium"], ''The New York Times'', December 20, 1980</ref> Poetry was Kolodney's greatest love: "At the center we had the greatest poets, [[T. S. Eliot|Eliot]], [[E. E. Cummings|Cummings]], [[Wallace Stevens|Stevens]]. Eliot turned down other institutions to read at the 'Y'".<ref>Kisselgoff, Anna. [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/10/13/102306223.html?pageNumber=53 "92d Street 'Y' Hails Education Chief"], ''The New York Times'', October 13, 1969, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> His favorite poet was [[Edward Arlington Robinson]].<ref>Schonberg, Harold. [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1959/09/13/88819047.html?action=click&contentCollection=Archives&module=ArticleEndCTA&region=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article&pageNumber=489 "And Also Poetry"], ''The New York Times'', September 13, 1959, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> In 1953 Kolodney arranged for the Poetry Center to present the first NY performance of [[Dylan Thomas]]'s ''[[Under Milkwood]]''.<ref>Smith, Dinitta. [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/05/19/arts/poetic-echoes-in-the-temple-60-years-of-y-and-whither.html "Poetic Echoes in the Temple; 60 Years of 'Y' and Whither"], ''The New York Times'', May 19, 1999, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> Kolodney attempted to compile a volume of "Y" Poetry Center poets' responses, including a letter from [[T.S. Eliot]], to the anti-Semitic 1952 [[Slánský trial]] in [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Czechoslovakia]], but the volume was never released.<ref>Eliot, T.S. ''[[Tradition (journal)|Tradition]]'', Vol. 5, No. 2 (Spring 1963), pp. 317–318</ref>
When he retired from the 92nd Street Y after 35 years in 1969, a ''New York Times'' editorial noted that he had made the "Y" "the source of some of the most varied and stimulating artistic fare in the nation. His view was ecumenical; the person was always submerged in the artist. He made the "Y" a stay against confusion, a place where for a moment all that is harmonious, stable, beautiful comes to rest."<ref>Editorial. [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/10/16/81994991.html?pageNumber=46 "Dr. Kolodney Retires"], ''The New York Times'', October 16, 1969, accessed July 25, 2017</ref>
==The Metropolitan Museum of Art== In 1954, while still Education Director at the 'Y', Kolodney created a music program at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. The Met had recently renovated the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium to feature arts programs.<ref>Cates, Meryl. [http://www.metmuseum.org/blogs/met-live-arts/2014/grr "Did You Know? The Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium Edition"], Metropolitan Museum of Art, October 21, 2014, accessed July 25, 2017</ref> The first season of concerts presented pianist [[Arthur Rubinstein]], violinist [[Isaac Stern]], folk singer [[Burl Ives]], and contralto [[Marian Anderson]].<ref>"Subscription Events for Members: Season 1954–1955", p. 2, The Metropolitan Museum of Art</ref> Three years later, Kolodney initiated a subscription series of lectures on art for the museum. Art historian [[Leo Steinberg]] launched the program with 10 lectures on "Change and Permanence in Western Art".<ref>"Art History Lecture Courses: 1957–1958" season program, p. 3, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, accessed August 13, 2017</ref> Kolodney continued to head the Concerts & Lectures series at the Met until 1968.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/press/news/2004/the-metropolitan-museum-of-art-announces-20042005-season-of-concerts-the-51st-season "The Metropolitan Museum of Art Announces 2004-2005 Season of Concerts, The 51st Season"], season program, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2004, accessed July 25, 2017</ref>
==Personal life== Kolodney died in [[Mamaroneck, New York]]. His children were Nathan, David and Rima.<ref name=NYTimesObit/>
